citations.narrative:
On May 4, 2024, an animal caretaker heard “squealing and a commotion” in a rabbit enclosure and upon investigation
found two male rabbits in an enclosure and one of the rabbits, #213, was unable to move or use its hind legs. Rabbit #213
was immediately euthanized. The rabbits are individually housed, and the second rabbit in the enclosure with #213 had
escaped from the neighboring enclosure. These rabbits are housed in racks of enclosures that have dividers between
adjacent enclosures that have a 2.25 inch gap at the top. The rabbit from the neighboring enclosure was small enough to
fit through that gap and get into #213’s enclosure. The animal caretaker for the rabbits said that smaller rabbits upon
arrival to the facility are sometimes able to fit through the gap at the top of the divider. The attending veterinarian
confirmed that the rabbits are single housed because the enclosures are too small to provide adequate social distancing
needed to safely pair house them. A post-mortem examination was done on rabbit #213 and the facility incident report
states that a “traumatic lumbar-sacral fracture was identified – likely sustained during a fight with the escaped cohort.”
Enclosures for rabbits need to be constructed in a way that securely contains them and protects then from injury. The
facility has two types of enclosures for individually housing rabbits and the type that has the gap at the top of the divider is
no longer in use since this incident.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian.
n

narrative:
3.53(a)(1)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
On May 4, 2024, an animal caretaker heard “squealing and a commotion” in a rabbit enclosure and upon investigation 
found two male rabbits in an enclosure and one of the rabbits, #213, was unable to move or use its hind legs. Rabbit #213 
was immediately euthanized. The rabbits are individually housed, and the second rabbit in the enclosure with #213 had 
escaped from the neighboring enclosure. These rabbits are housed in racks of enclosures that have dividers between 
adjacent enclosures that have a 2.25 inch gap at the top. The rabbit from the neighboring enclosure was small enough to 
fit through that gap and get into #213’s enclosure. The animal caretaker for the rabbits said that smaller rabbits upon 
arrival to the facility are sometimes able to fit through the gap at the top of the divider. The attending veterinarian 
confirmed that the rabbits are single housed because the enclosures are too small to provide adequate social distancing 
needed to safely pair house them. A post-mortem examination was done on rabbit #213 and the facility incident report 
states that a “traumatic lumbar-sacral fracture was identified – likely sustained during a fight with the escaped cohort.”  
Enclosures for rabbits need to be constructed in a way that securely contains them and protects then from injury. The 
facility has two types of enclosures for individually housing rabbits and the type that has the gap at the top of the divider is 
no longer in use since this incident. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian. 
 
 n
